title: 104_hr3228
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS." is a condensed summary of the section title and findings. The "65th Infantry Regiment Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the bravery of Puerto Rican soldiers in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. They fought heroically and were awarded honors for their service. The 65th Infantry Regiment of Puerto Rican soldiers played a crucial role in rescuing the 1st Division of the United States Marine Corps in Hagaru-ri during the Korean conflict. They provided a safe corridor for the Marines to escape and formed a protective rear guard during the retreat to Hungnam. The regiment was the last to leave the beachhead in the Christmas eve evacuation of Hungnam on December 24, 1950. The 65th Infantry Regiment of Puerto Rican soldiers saved the 3d Infantry Division from a North Korean attack, receiving accolades for their heroism in battle, including a letter from General Douglas MacArthur. The 65th Infantry Regiment of Puerto Rican soldiers demonstrated valor and loyalty on the battlefields of Korea, earning praise from General Douglas MacArthur for their achievements in battle. In commemoration of the Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment who fought in the Korean conflict, the Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design of the coins will be determined as per the Act. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the courage and valor of Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "1997", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various veterans' organizations. The design of the coins minted under this Act will symbolize the courage and valor of Puerto Ricans in the 65th Infantry Regiment during the Korean conflict. The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with veterans' organizations and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility starting January 1, 1997, with minting authority ending on December 31, 1997. The Secretary shall sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of design. Bulk sales at a discount are allowed. Prepaid orders are accepted with a discount. A $10 surcharge per coin is included in all sales. SEC. 7 of the Act waives procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 addresses the distribution of surcharges. All surcharges from the sale of coins under this Act go to the Korean War Veterans Memorial Fund for the American Battle Monuments Commission to use. The Commission can use the funds for costs related to the Korean War Veterans Memorial or for a ceremony for the 65th regiment after consulting with the National Congress for Puerto Rican Veterans. The National Congress for Puerto Rican Veterans, Puerto Rican Veterans In Massachusetts Association, and Puerto Rican-American Research Institute conduct a ceremony at the Korean War Veterans Memorial honoring the Puerto Ricans of the 65th Infantry Regiment for their service during the Korean conflict. The Comptroller General of the United States can audit the American Battle Monuments Commission's expenditures related to the funds allocated for the Memorial. SEC. 9. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The Secretary must ensure minting coins won't cost the government. Coins can't be issued without full payment, security, or a guarantee of payment from a depository institution.
